case_title: JAI KISHAN SRIVASTAVA vs INCOME-TAX OFFICER, KANPUR, AND ANOTHER

accussed_details.name: JAI KISHAN SRIVASTAVA
allegation: Failure to disclose material facts necessary for assessment
Escaped assessment of income for years 1940-41 to 1946-47

complaint_summary: The petitioner was issued notices under Section 34(1-A) of the Income-tax Act for reassessment of income for the years 1940-41 to 1946-47, alleging evasion of taxes exceeding Rs. 1,00,000 during the war period.
investigation_summary: The petitioner was initially investigated under the Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947, but proceedings were abandoned due to the Commission's dissolution following Supreme Court rulings. Subsequently, notices under Section 34(1-A) were issued for reassessment.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the validity of Section 34(1-A) of the Income-tax Act, rejecting claims of discrimination under Article 14 of the Constitution. It ruled that the procedure under Section 34(1-A) aligns with principles of natural justice and does not deny rights of appeal or reference.
legal_arguments: Section 34(1-A) does not violate Article 14 of the Constitution.
The procedure under Section 34(1-A) aligns with principles of natural justice.
No discrimination exists between Section 34(1) and Section 34(1-A) in terms of procedure and rights.
statutes: Article 14 of the Constitution of India
key_issues: Validity of Section 34(1-A) under Article 14 of the Constitution
Discrimination in procedure and limitation under Section 34(1-A)
Bias of Income-tax Officer in quasi-judicial proceedings
summary_vector_notes: The case involved the validity of Section 34(1-A) of the Income-tax Act, challenged under Article 14 of the Constitution. The court ruled that the section does not violate constitutional guarantees of equality and provides adequate procedural safeguards. The petitions were dismissed.
